body:
> I'd prefer to move your categorical isin logic to a new method Categorical.isin.

To be a bit clearer about this. I'd imagine the `Categorical.isin` method doing the codes and categories stuff, to see which codes the items in `values` would map to. Then calling `algorithms.value_counts(codes, code_values)`, where `code_values` is the code that each value maps to (if any).
@TomAugspurger Why do I need to call `algorithms.value_counts(codes, code_values)` in `Categorical.isin`? Do you mean `algorithms.isin`?

Sorry, I meant `isin` :)

On Wed, Mar 28, 2018 at 5:30 PM, Artem Bogachev <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> @TomAugspurger <https://github.com/TomAugspurger> Why do I need to call algorithms.value_counts(codes,
> code_values) in Categorical.isin
>

Merged in master. That'll hopefully fix the circleCI failure.
@ma3axaka did you run the ASV benchmarks? Or just a simple `%timeit` before / after? How does the performance look?

> What are the possible argument types that can be used in Series.isin for example?

It looks like it can be just about anything.  Did you run into issues without using `_sanitize_array`?
Yep. I have run the `asv` benchmark. I got the positive result. Do I need to post them here?

Sure (just the new one). I'm curious to see the performance improvement.

I've already added the line about the performance improvement to `whatsnew`. Do I need to add another one?
Sorry, missed that.

That's what I got on my laptop from `asv`:
```
       before           after         ratio
     [fac2ef1b]       [d6c39534]
-         230±6ms      17.6±0.01ms     0.08  categoricals.IsIn.time_isin_categorical_strings
```
@jreback Changed the condition to `hasattr`

Sorry, I just noticed an issue. You've made the changes in `Series.isin`, so that the performance boost won't apply to other cases, most notably `CategoricalIndex.isin`.

We have a couple ways to proceed. IMO, I think it's best for the container classes `Series.isin` and `Index.isin` to be as simple as possible. Really just calling `algos.isin(self, values)` *without coercing the data.*

In `algos.isin` we'll unbox the series / index to get the underlying array (numpy array or categorical).

If we find a Categorical, we dispatch to `Categorical.isin`, which extracts the codes, and calls algos.isin again with the codes. Just like you've done.

So the order would be Series.isin -> algos.isin(categorical) -> Categorical.isin -> algos.isin(categorical).

In terms of code changes, it'll be

1. Ensure that `algos.isin` dispatches to `Categorical.isin`
2. Ensure that `algos.isin` does the `_values_from_object` stuff that's currently in `Series.isin` and `Index.isin`. (I think it's already doing that in `ensure_data`, so we may have been doing it twice originally.


Does that make sense?
Yes. It makes sense. I will try to refactor it the way you've proposed.
If you're feeling ambitious, you can make a shared doc between algorithms.isin & Categorical.isin (see factorize).
@TomAugspurger I cannot reproduce CI errors locally. What is the best way to proceed here?

Something strange with Py2.

```python
(Pdb) code_values[null_mask | (code_values >= 0)]
array([1, 1])
```

The reason is that `null_mask` is boolean series, since `values` was a `Categorical` (same would happen with a Series).

```python
(Pdb) null_mask
0    False
1    False
dtype: bool
```

Casting it to an array seems to help

```python
(Pdb) code_values[np.asarray(null_mask) | (code_values >= 0)]
array([0, 1])
```

Are you able to setup a python2 environment to test locally?
I would prefer to convert `values` to `ndarray` before this logic. Is there any function I could use to safely do it?

use np.asarray as
tom suggests

Hello @ma3axaka! Thanks for updating the PR.













Cheers ! There are no PEP8 issues in this Pull Request. :beers: 

##### Comment last updated on April 25, 2018 at 10:02 Hours UTC
@TomAugspurger @jreback I have added the docs and fixed the problem with Python 2 (thanks to @TomAugspurger). Is there something else to be done?

@jreback I have renamed the benchmark class and a reference to the issue. Switching to `is_extension_type` doesn't work. It fails on `SparseArray` for example the class doesn't have `isin` method. I am assuming implementing these methods is the goal of #20617?
@jreback I've made requested changes except moving tests to a different file (see comments). But the Travis CI build is failing with an S3 error.
@jreback There are still errors with S3. Is this OK?

I'm looking into the s3 / moto issues today. Things should be OK on your
end.
